entry.title: Combined summary - Benchmarking Bitcoin Script Evaluation for the Varops Budget (Great Script Restoration)
entry.summary: The introduction of a new Tapscript leaf version aims to mitigate denial-of-service attacks on the Bitcoin network by generalizing the sigops budget into a varops budget. This adjustment allows for a proportional allocation of compute units based on transaction weight, setting a current rate of 5,200 units per weight unit. The approach emphasizes the importance of benchmarking to establish a baseline for script performance, particularly focusing on block-sized scripts to gauge the slowest possible validation scenarios within the system's computational constraints. Benchmark tests include various operations to determine their performance under the varops budget, using Schnorr signature validations as a comparative benchmark to ensure execution times remain within acceptable limits. Community involvement is crucial in refining the varops budget, with developers encouraged to participate in benchmarking efforts through the GSR prototype implementation. The process involves meticulous configuration of build options to ensure that the benchmarks are precise and comparable across different systems. Issues such as script errors and the cap on the varops budget highlight areas for improvement in methodology, suggesting a need for revisions in how the budget is applied and how opcode costs are assessed. A new GitHub repository ([https://github.com/jmoik/varopsData](https://github.com/jmoik/varopsData)) has been established to facilitate the sharing and analysis of benchmark data. The initiative underscores the significance of collaborative data handling and transparent reporting in programming projects. Moreover, the discussion delves into the implications of signature verification times, specifically those of Schnorr signatures, and their potential impact on the Bitcoin ecosystem, including concerns over the average verification time per block and its effects on network responsiveness and Initial Block Download (IBD) times. The conversation further explores the practical aspects of blockchain validation, suggesting that the actual process could be significantly quicker than the worst-case scenario suggests. It highlights the 'assumevalid' feature as a critical optimization for reducing IBD times, indicating that most scripts are not fully validated during this process. Additionally, the dialogue touches upon the efficiency gains possible through smarter validation strategies and multi-threaded processing, which can mitigate delays associated with intensive validation tasks. Lastly, the potential of new opcodes, such as those enabling zero-knowledge proofs, is considered, reflecting on the capacity of blockchain technology to handle complex operations within current limitations. This exploration points to the necessity of reevaluating the computational budget and optimization strategies to accommodate advancements in blockchain functionality and security, moving beyond mitigations for past issues to embrace the possibilities of future developments.
